comment_text: Understanding the meaning of life is individual and cannot be solved by a five step plan as you say. I feel that meaning comes about from your relationships with your family your friends, your enemies and so on. Meaning is the story that you create through life experience. I think today there is a lack of meaning in the young people because they think in this environment that has been created that you can solve anything and yes as example, the five step program but  nothing resonates with them.  I think religion came about to answer the questions people had about why is the rain not falling and our crops dying why did my two-year-old son die etc. etc. and in different cultures they came up with different answers.  And lastly, before the modern age and mega cities, people were born into a particular tribal culture and pretty much stayed in that place. Today with all the information that we can conjure up with a touch of a finger, there‚Äôs a lot of information and possibly that is part of the confusion. Even your program if I listen intently causes confusion.üá®üá¶
author: @deborahhebblethwaite1865
cleaned_text: understanding the meaning of life is individual and cannot be solved by a five step plan as you say. i feel that meaning comes about from your relationships with your family your friends, your enemies and so on. meaning is the story that you create through life experience. i think today there is a lack of meaning in the young people because they think in this environment that has been created that you can solve anything and yes as example, the five step program but  nothing resonates with them.  i think religion came about to answer the questions people had about why is the rain not falling and our crops dying why did my two-year-old son die etc. etc. and in different cultures they came up with different answers.  and lastly, before the modern age and mega cities, people were born into a particular tribal culture and pretty much stayed in that place. today with all the information that we can conjure up with a touch of a finger, theres a lot of information and possibly that is part of the confusion. even your program if i listen intently causes confusion.

video_title: Atheist vs Christian vs Spiritual Thinker: The Paperclip Problem That Exposes Religion!
comment_text: Gosh I woke up with a plan for the day.mainly chores.med taken...tick.lymphatic massage and exercises....tick.I come across this video.I watched the whole of it with Mr Tinnitus by my side.How I wish it was subtitled.what did I learn from it, my background being in mental Health....It is to work on :who am I.whst is my sense of meaning.what is my purpose in the here and now.can I challenge myself to that purpose with the right structure and direction.dodging  external forces slowing me down.can I keep  up that motivation.when experienced trauma shatters me, how to act upon it so my ego does not become maladaptive.Imstill working at balancing my Johari's window the best I can.and looking at my consciousness level.oh I dream every night.it is tiring! The best thing I believe in here is something very little can change or improve one not always a big thing does that.An example in my work.im fully retired now at 72.There was this  26 year old guy who has been in an institution most of his life.Aggressive...heavily medicated...scary.Nothing seems to work.he was looking at a car magazine one day and we started talking about cars....A guy I employed  was previously a mechanic.so I suggested we take him him for a drive.first time ever.showing the gear, the wheel etc.We open the bonnet to show him.His eyes brightened! then got an old ford put it in a garage on the grounds with a manual...All these years we thought we were doing the best we could for him.no change but from that first drive.he became better and the aggression became non existent.medication were decreased then stopped.The point of this story is we just found just a little thing that mattered to him.to result to a better quality of life, not the management for years by our "big"multi disciplinary team.It is a matter of finding and exploring it.my 50 cents!
author: @lisettelevantard3400
cleaned_text: gosh i woke up with a plan for the day.mainly chores.med taken...tick.lymphatic massage and exercises....tick.i come across this video.i watched the whole of it with mr tinnitus by my side.how i wish it was subtitled.what did i learn from it, my background being in mental health....it is to work on :who am i.whst is my sense of meaning.what is my purpose in the here and now.can i challenge myself to that purpose with the right structure and direction.dodging  external forces slowing me down.can i keep  up that motivation.when experienced trauma shatters me, how to act upon it so my ego does not become maladaptive.imstill working at balancing my johari's window the best i can.and looking at my consciousness level.oh i dream every night.it is tiring! the best thing i believe in here is something very little can change or improve one not always a big thing does that.an example in my work.im fully retired now at 72.there was this  26 year old guy who has been in an institution most of his life.aggressive...heavily medicated...scary.nothing seems to work.he was looking at a car magazine one day and we started talking about cars....a guy i employed  was previously a mechanic.so i suggested we take him him for a drive.first time ever.showing the gear, the wheel etc.we open the bonnet to show him.his eyes brightened! then got an old ford put it in a garage on the grounds with a manual...all these years we thought we were doing the best we could for him.no change but from that first drive.he became better and the aggression became non existent.medication were decreased then stopped.the point of this story is we just found just a little thing that mattered to him.to result to a better quality of life, not the management for years by our "big"multi disciplinary team.it is a matter of finding and exploring it.my 50 cents!

video_title: Atheist vs Christian vs Spiritual Thinker: The Paperclip Problem That Exposes Religion!
comment_text:
The atheist presented interesting philosophical ideas and explanations. ‚ÄúDo I know my own purpose‚Ä¶assumes there is a purpose to know,‚Äù and ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve eliminated the daily survival need which has led to this [existential] crisis‚Äù of what do we do now. Theism, or anything else, bringing positive meaning (or detriment) to an individual does not mean that it is truth. His ideas on consciousness were very interesting. 

What the ‚Äúspiritual‚Äù psychiatrist describes, (over and over yikes) as ‚Äúquantifiable,‚Äù that specific action having a neurobiological effect leading to feeling less depressed and finding meaning‚Ä¶is essentially therapy. Yes, therapy can shift your mental/physical state, and it‚Äôs lovely that he helps people, but that doesn‚Äôt answer any existential questions about why people cannot find purpose, and is that universal.

I think that Stephen presented some great examples with friends who were both feeling down. None of the guests truly answered these questions and yet they each thought that they did. 

The Christian said that meaning will be found in religion and belief in higher power. 
The psychiatrist said that meaning is found in both a higher power and after a person does therapeutic work that affects their brain. 
The atheist says that meaning was evolutionarily diminished, and this is why we are feel aimless and lost, and anything else is subjective thought, and not necessarily truth. 

I think it was absolutely brilliant to bring all three of these different viewpoints together. Even if most of it was not fascinating, all are worth hearing. Of course we can feel better with belief in a higher power, like the friend in Dubai, because then we are connected to something greater than ourselves. (Though it was still shocking to hear a person state that the subjective feeling was ‚Äúevidence‚Äù of truth. Erm, no.) Of course we can find meaning and purpose by changing our neurobiological chemistry through therapeutic action, but we also need to understand our own existence when we are intellectual. Of course we will have more time to ponder why we are here and what we should be doing when we are no longer being chased by Sabre tooth cats. I believe that this evolutionary understanding is what benefits me the most. Then they can choose to integrate therapy, spirituality, etc. Each of these viewpoints expressed are relevant to someone. 

Humans are complex, social beings with the leisure to think about their own existence. I think about my childhood and how everything was about joy in the moment, playing was paramount, and how life through my limited ancillary lens resulted in a less complicated world. As children we also are never alone at the start, nearly always spending time with other people. 

Now we are all more and more separated via technology. We spend too much time alone, in our own technology bubble. We compare ourselves to others in ways that never existed throughout history, which can lead to feeling inadequate and unfulfilled. People are struggling and suffering all over the world, which we are acutely aware of‚Ä¶and evil, for lack of a better word, conflict, impending doom, destruction of the planet, and acute fear are pervasive and normalized, extinguishing childhood ideals. 

It‚Äôs not all that complicated that existence in a modern world has lead to humans becoming more complex. We have all the information, yet there is no single answer.
author: @TessaLeigh
cleaned_text:

what the spiritual psychiatrist describes, (over and over yikes) as quantifiable, that specific action having a neurobiological effect leading to feeling less depressed and finding meaningis essentially therapy. yes, therapy can shift your mental/physical state, and its lovely that he helps people, but that doesnt answer any existential questions about why people cannot find purpose, and is that universal.

(though it was still shocking to hear a person state that the subjective feeling was evidence of truth. erm, no.) of course we can find meaning and purpose by changing our neurobiological chemistry through therapeutic action, but we also need to understand our own existence when we are intellectual. of course we will have more time to ponder why we are here and what we should be doing when we are no longer being chased by sabre tooth cats. i believe that this evolutionary understanding is what benefits me the most. then they can choose to integrate therapy, spirituality, etc. each of these viewpoints expressed are relevant to someone.

now we are all more and more separated via technology. we spend too much time alone, in our own technology bubble. we compare ourselves to others in ways that never existed throughout history, which can lead to feeling inadequate and unfulfilled. people are struggling and suffering all over the world, which we are acutely aware ofand evil, for lack of a better word, conflict, impending doom, destruction of the planet, and acute fear are pervasive and normalized, extinguishing childhood ideals.

video_title: Atheist vs Christian vs Spiritual Thinker: The Paperclip Problem That Exposes Religion!
comment_text: I find this an interesting discussion, but feel the premise is a bit off.  First, it would have been lovely to have included a feminine voice in the discussion.  This conversation definitely had a masculine skew, IMO. People often find purpose and meaning being on any side of a religious or spiritual position. Consider the possibility that there can be a hierarchy of meaning and purpose. Theories of developmental psychology and pediatrics often focus on purpose early in life.  As we mature we replace that purpose with learning to set appropriate goals and achievements. If we continue in that maturation we develop a deeper inner awareness that reveals a correspondingly deeper and richer sense of purpose. Modern technology with social media and gaming hacks the dopamine reward system and highjacks our evolution of purpose and reduces the lives of some people to that ascribed by the social media or games.
author: @TamaleeAndersen-i9h
cleaned_text: i find this an interesting discussion, but feel the premise is a bit off.  first, it would have been lovely to have included a feminine voice in the discussion.  this conversation definitely had a masculine skew, imo. people often find purpose and meaning being on any side of a religious or spiritual position. consider the possibility that there can be a hierarchy of meaning and purpose. theories of developmental psychology and pediatrics often focus on purpose early in life.  as we mature we replace that purpose with learning to set appropriate goals and achievements. if we continue in that maturation we develop a deeper inner awareness that reveals a correspondingly deeper and richer sense of purpose. modern technology with social media and gaming hacks the dopamine reward system and highjacks our evolution of purpose and reduces the lives of some people to that ascribed by the social media or games.

comment_text: You don‚Äôt need a religious story to feel grounded. For some of us, it‚Äôs more solid to anchor life in reality itself, science and evidence that actually hold up. The universe is vast and awe-inspiring enough to give a deep sense of connection, and human values like empathy and fairness guide how we live together. Relationships and community bring stability, and purpose can be created through growth, health, creativity, and making the world better. And instead of filling every unknown with a made-up answer, there‚Äôs real strength in the humility of saying ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt know yet.‚Äù That‚Äôs a foundation built on truth, not myth.
